skill.name: orchestration
skill.description: Skills for orchestrating tasks across multiple AI providers and execution environments. Parent skill category containing native-invoke and related delegation patterns.
skill.summary: Skills for orchestrating tasks across multiple AI providers and execution environments. Parent skill...
skill.author: Consiliency

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation/guide skill containing only markdown files. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access, and no command execution capabilities. The skill describes workflows for using Claude Code's native Task tool to invoke external AI providers. All behavior matches stated purpose.

content.value_statement: Managing multiple AI coding providers requires understanding their unique capabilities and command patterns. This skill provides documentation and workflows for delegating tasks to Claude, Codex, Gemini, and Cursor with proper authentication, read-only safeguards, and fallback strategies.
actual_capabilities: Route tasks to optimal AI providers based on context size and task complexity
Execute parallel agents across multiple providers for comprehensive analysis
Configure read-only mode and worktree isolation for safe agent execution
Handle authentication failures with fork-terminal fallback patterns
Collect and synthesize results from native Task agent invocations
Optimize costs by selecting appropriate providers for each task type
limitations: This is a documentation skill only; it does not execute code or invoke CLIs directly
Requires users to configure CLI permissions in .claude/settings.json manually
External AI provider CLIs (codex, gemini, cursor-agent) must be installed separately

use_cases.title: Multi-Provider Code Analysis
use_cases.description: Route security audits to Codex for sandboxing and Gemini for large context analysis in parallel

use_cases.title: Provider Fallback Automation
use_cases.description: Implement fallback chains so tasks automatically retry with alternative providers on failure

use_cases.title: Cross-Provider Benchmarking
use_cases.description: Run identical prompts across Claude, Codex, and Gemini to compare results and capabilities

prompt_templates.title: Select provider
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to delegate a task to an external AI provider. First, read the native-invoke cookbook to understand the provider-specific flags. The task is: [TASK_DESCRIPTION]. Which provider should I use and what command should I construct?

prompt_templates.title: Parallel execution
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a parallel analysis using Codex for sandboxed security scanning and Gemini for architecture review. Use the Task tool with run_in_background=true for both. Construct non-interactive commands per the cookbook patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Auth recovery
prompt_templates.prompt: The native agent returned an authentication error. Detect the provider from the error message, then trigger the fork-terminal fallback to run the login command interactively. After login completes, retry the original invocation.

prompt_templates.title: Worktree isolation
prompt_templates.prompt: I need an agent to make file changes. Create an isolated git worktree for this task, invoke the agent with full write permissions, then help me review the changes before merging back to main. Clean up the worktree if I reject the changes.

output_examples.input: I need to analyze a 200k token codebase for security vulnerabilities using sandboxed execution
output: âœ“ Routing to Codex (best for sandboxed execution)
âœ“ Constructed command: codex exec --sandbox read-only --full-auto --model gpt-5.2-codex 'Security audit'
âœ“ Execute via Task tool with run_in_background: true
âœ“ Collect results via TaskOutput after completion

best_practices: Always run --help on the CLI before constructing commands to verify available flags
Use read-only mode or worktree isolation when agents need to analyze code you want to preserve
Implement fallback chains so tasks retry with alternative providers on auth failure or timeout
anti_patterns: Skipping the cookbook read step and constructing commands from memory
Using interactive flags (-i) with native Task agents that cannot handle TTY input
Running agents without cleanup protocols, leaving agent-created files in the repository

faq.question: Which AI tools support native Task agent invocation?
faq.answer: Claude Code supports native agents for OpenAI Codex, Google Gemini, and Cursor Agent. Each requires specific CLI flags for non-interactive execution.

faq.question: What are the context limits for each provider?
faq.answer: Claude Opus: 200k tokens. Gemini 3 Pro: 2M tokens. Codex: 32k tokens. Cursor inherits context from the IDE.

faq.question: How do I integrate this skill with my existing workflow?
faq.answer: Configure permissions in .claude/settings.json for each provider's CLI. Then use the Task tool with subagent_type='general-purpose' following the cookbook patterns.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using external providers?
faq.answer: Use read-only mode or worktree isolation to protect your codebase. Read-only mode prevents modifications; worktrees create isolated copies for agent changes.

faq.question: What happens if authentication fails?
faq.answer: The skill documents detection patterns for auth failures. Trigger fork-terminal to run login commands interactively, then retry the original task.

faq.question: How does this compare to using Claude directly?
faq.answer: This skill orchestrates external providers for specialized tasks. Claude Code remains your primary agent; external providers supplement for sandboxing, large context, or IDE integration.
